title: Pupil
s1: platform for eyetracking and egocentric vision research
pupil_description_1: A platform for eye tracking and egocentric vision research
pupil_description_2: Pupil headsets are 3D printed frames that you wear like a pair of glasses. The hardware is designed as a modular system that can be configured to support your research and application requirments.
pupil_description_3: Connect your Pupil headset to a Linux, MacOS, or Windows computer via USB
pupil_description_4: Pupil Capture is the software used with your Pupil headset.
pupil_description_5: Pupil Capture recieves video and audio streams, detects your pupil, tracks your gaze and tracks markers in your environment, stream data in real-time over the network, and records data in an open format.
pupil_description_6: Pupil Player is a media and data visualizer at its core. You will use it to look at Pupil Capture recordings.
pupil_description_7: Visualize your data and export it. All Pupil software is open-source. You can modify it or write your own plugins to suit your needs.
pupil_description_8: We believe in open source. All Pupil code is released with open source licenses.
pupil_description_9: A lot of work went into making the software modular and accessible. The majority of the codebase is written in Python.
pupil_description_10: We have developed a plugin structure that enables you to extend Pupil Capture and Pupil Player to suit your needs.
pupil_image_1_alt: We believe in open source. All Pupil code is released with open source licenses.
pupil_description_11: A lot of design and engineering thought has gone into getting the ergonomics of the headset just right.
pupil_description_12: It is designed to fit snugly, securely, and comfortably. The headset and cameras can be adjusted to accommodate a wide range of users. The headset is made from laser sintered PA12, an extremely flexible, durable, and lightweight material.
pupil_image_2_alt: A lot of design and engineering thought has gone into getting the ergonomics of the headset just right
pupil_description_13: Eye tracking performance is determined in equal parts by the hardware and software. We constantly work on our algorithms and codebase, so you can expect a steady improvement and the latest features.
pupil_description_16: Latency 5.7 ms (using 120hz eye and high speed world cameras)
pupil_description_17: If we don't have the configuration you need, customize it yourself. Our camera mount geometry and electrical interface is open. We also like to work with users to create custom solutions. Get in touch if you're excited about SMD soldering and hacking: you can buy a DEV frame, buy parts, and follow assembly instructions to build your own Pupil DEV headset.
pupil_image_3_alt: If we don't have the configuration you need, customize it yourself.
pupil_description_18: Pupil is driven by an active community.
pupil_description_19: Make a fork of the Pupil Github repository and start developing.
pupil_description_20: Read the docs and contribute to the user guide.
pupil_description_21: Discuss your project and get free support.
pupil_description_22: We offer dedicated email and video training and support packages.
pupil_description_23: See support packages in the store.
pupil_description_24: We offer use licenses to commercial users.
pupil_description_25: Contact us to discuss custom licensing options.
